message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Anhedonia and depressed mood are the cardinal symptoms of major depressive disorder. A history of elated mood is more consistent with bipolar disorder. Preserved social and occupational functioning is not typical of major depressive disorder. Symptoms must be present for at least 2 weeks, not 1 month as stated in the question.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Anhedonia or depressed mood are some of the symptoms that must be present for a diagnosis of major depressive disorder. There is no mention in the case of a history of elated mood or preserved social and occupational functioning. The symptoms must be present for at least 2 weeks, not 1 month as stated in option D.

We refer to Medscape articles on psychiatry for help. Anhedonia or depressed mood is a required symptom for major depressive disorder diagnosis. Option B is incorrect because major depressive disorder excludes a history of elated mood. Option C is incorrect because major depressive disorder is associated with impairment in social and occupational functioning. Option D is partially correct, as symptoms must be present for at least 2 weeks, not 1 month.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Anhedonia or depressed mood is one of the diagnostic criteria for major depressive disorder. The other options are not necessarily true for all patients with major depressive disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Anhedonia or depressed mood are key symptoms of major depressive disorder, and must be present for at least 2 weeks, according to DSM-5 criteria. Options B and C are not true, as elated mood may indicate bipolar disorder or substance use disorder, and major depressive disorder may interfere with social and occupational functioning. Option D is incorrect, as symptoms must be present for at least 2 weeks, not 1 month.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Anhedonia or depressed mood are key symptoms of major depressive disorder. Option B is incorrect because elated mood is associated with bipolar disorder rather than major depressive disorder. Option C is incorrect because major depressive disorder often disrupts social and occupational functioning. Option D is incorrect because symptoms only need to be present for at least 2 weeks, not 1 month.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Anhedonia or depressed mood is required for major depressive disorder diagnosis. Option B is incorrect as elated mood would suggest a bipolar disorder diagnosis. Option C is incorrect as the patient is unable to go to work. Option D is incorrect as the symptoms must be present for at least 2 weeks, not 1 month.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Major depressive disorder is characterized by either anhedonia or depressed mood, as well as other symptoms such as weight loss, loss of interest or pleasure in activities, and feelings of worthlessness or guilt. The patient may or may not have a history of elated mood. Preserved social and occupational functioning is not characteristic of major depressive disorder. The symptoms must be present for at least 2 weeks, not 1 month as stated in the answer choices.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Anhedonia or depressed mood is one of the diagnostic criteria for major depressive disorder. There is no requirement for a history of elated mood, and social and occupational functioning may be impaired. Symptoms must be present for at least 2 weeks, not 1 month.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Anhedonia or depressed mood is one of the two core symptoms for major depressive disorder. Elated mood suggests bipolar disorder, which is different from major depressive disorder. The patient has had a significant loss of occupational functioning due to cancer, which is not preserved. The symptoms must have been present for at least 2 weeks, not 1 month.
